sentence: The Home Depot Inc. ( HD ), the world's largest home improvement retailer, released first-quarter fiscal 2015 results, wherein adjusted earnings of $1.16 a share beat the Zacks Consensus Estimate by a penny.
Moreover, the bottom line jumped 16% from $1.00 a share earned in the year-ago quarter.
Taking one-time items, the company's quarterly earnings came in at $1.21 per share, up 21% year-over-year.
Following the better-than-expected results, the company raised its sales and earnings outlook for fiscal 2015.
As a result, sales are now expected to increase in the range of 4.2%-4.8%, as against 3.5%-4.7% predicted earlier.
Comparable store sales are expected to grow in a range of 4.0%- 4.6%, up from the previous range of 3.3%-4.5%.
Earnings per share is now envisioned in a band of $5.24- $5.27, compared to $5.11-$5.17, projected earlier.
Earnings Estimate Revision: The Zacks Consensus fiscal 2015 Estimate portrays an uptrend in the last 30 days.
Moreover, in the trailing four quarters (including the quarter under review), the company has outperformed the Zacks Consensus Estimate by an average of 5.1%.
Revenues: Home Depot's net sales increased 6.1% year over year to $20,891 million, also surpassing the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $20,775 million.
Comparable store sales grew 6.1%.
The company's results gained from spring season sales and the ongoing U.S. housing market recovery.
Key Events: Home Depot declared some accounting policy changes in the reported quarter.
The company will now record certain shipping and handling costs under "cost of sales" instead of recording them under "operating expenses."
Zacks Rank: Currently, Home Depot carries a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold) which is subject to change following the earnings announcement.
Check back later for our full write up on Home Depot's earnings report!
